text_en: As a leader
text_pl: you receive information that is formally legal but ethically uncomfortable and could provide strategic advantage. What do you do first?
column10: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Use the information – responsibility lies with the source"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Consult informally with a trusted colleague"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Delay the decision and seek an alternative source"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Reject using the information regardless of cost"}]

text_en: The board expects a fast decision. You know more time would improve quality
text_pl: but delay may be seen as lack of decisiveness.

text_en: In the same week a key manager leaves
options_json: and media pressure escalates. Which area gets your attention first?

text_en: Under overload
text_pl: how do you usually react internally? (from focused mobilisation to irritation and decision shortcutting)

text_en: A powerful stakeholder presents a solution as the only realistic option
text_pl: supported by authority and time pressure. Your reaction?
column10: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Accept – pragmatism is required"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Ask for alternatives"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Check who actually benefits"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Postpone despite pressure"}]

text_en: How often do you change your position not because of new data
text_pl: but because the power context has shifted?

text_en: During the day you receive many urgent inputs. Which best describes your style?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"I react continuously"},{"value":"B","label_en":"I delegate most of them"},{"value":"C","label_en":"I separate urgent from important"},{"value":"D","label_en":"I block access and return to priorities"}]

text_en: What most often steals your attention in critical moments?
A decision is formally yours
text_pl: but the team is divided. What role do you take?
column10: [{"value":"A","label_en":"I decide alone"},{"value":"B","label_en":"I build consensus"},{"value":"C","label_en":"I delegate responsibility"},{"value":"D","label_en":"I postpone the decision"}]

text_en: When was the last time you changed a decision because someone lower in the hierarchy was right?
A small deviation from standards brings short-term benefit and no resistance. What is your first thought?
Which statement is closer to you?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"The goal sometimes justifies the means"},{"value":"B","label_en":"The means define the leader, not the goal"}]

text_en: You can save a key contract by accepting a clause that is industry standard but misleading for the client. What do you do?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Accept – everyone does it"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Accept but clarify in an annex"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Renegotiate even at the cost of the deal"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Escalate to legal/compliance and pause"}]

text_en: A trusted director makes a mistake that could surface. The team suggests managing the narrative. How do you react?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Protect the person – stability matters"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Minimise risk and tidy communication"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Choose full transparency even if painful"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Disclose only what is strictly necessary"}]

text_en: When you are chronically overloaded
column10: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Empathy and patience"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Decision quality (shortcuts)"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Control and micromanagement"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Nothing – I function the same"}]

text_en: After a very difficult week
text_pl: what do you do in the first 24 hours?
column10: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Work more – cannot afford to slow down"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Sleep and disconnect"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Conduct a quick AAR, then rest"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Meet people and sense the temperature"}]

text_en: You receive a polished presentation with selective data and strong pressure to decide. Your first move?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Accept and negotiate details"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Request raw data and methodology"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Ask for a devil’s advocate case"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Delay – it smells wrong"}]

text_en: A stakeholder says: “If we don’t do this now
options_json: high conviction. What do you do?
column11: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Give in – risk is too high"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Ask three questions: data, source, alternatives"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Run a fast 2x2 scenario with the team"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Limit scope and run a test step"}]

text_en: Your organisation normalises interruption and urgency. What do you do as a leader?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Introduce focus blocks and escalation rules"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Increase control meetings"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Enforce more reporting"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Trust it will self-correct"}]

text_en: In a crisis you have 30 seconds to define priority for the team. Which is closer?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Do everything necessary"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Protect people and continuity first"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Save KPIs – that’s what we’re judged on"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Wait for full data to avoid mistakes"}]

text_en: Someone publicly challenges your decision in a meeting. What do you do?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Shut it down – return later"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Invite argument and discussion"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Treat it as disloyalty and react hard"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Move to 1:1 and separate emotion from merit"}]

text_en: You see small ethical deviations becoming normalised in the team. Your natural reaction?
reverse_scored: [{"value":"A","label_en":"Ignore – delivery matters"},{"value":"B","label_en":"Stop it immediately and name the standard"},{"value":"C","label_en":"Allow exceptions with a minimum threshold"},{"value":"D","label_en":"Trigger audit/compliance and reset process"}]
